title: BPM
content: Note lengths don’t represent the exact amount of time a note is played for - this is instead defined by the speed of the piece. Most pieces of sheet music will have a symbol indicating the Beats Per Minute, or BPM for short. For example, the symbol above means there are 100 crotchet beats per minute.

title: Crotchet
content: A crotchet is the simplest note - it lasts exactly one beat.

title: Quaver
content: A quaver is half a crotchet - it lasts half a beat.

title: Semiquaver
content: A semiquaver is half a quaver (semi means half). It lasts one quarter of a beat. There are smaller lengths than semiquavers (all the way down to hemidemisemiquavers, which last one sixty-fourth of a beat!), but we won’t be covering those in this topic.

title: Minim
content: A minim is the next length up from a crotchet, lasting two beats.

title: Semibreve
content: A semibreve is the longest commonly used length, lasting 4 beats!
